reviews.text: Three of us stayed in 2 of the lodge’s motel rooms in mid-July, 2009. (The motel building is separate from the lodge.) We made reservations for dinner at the lodge (at a reasonable cost) when we booked our room, and our hosts, Verna and Al, provided a wonderful family-style meal along with delightful conversation. A continental breakfast is served in the same relaxed atmosphere.
reviews.title: Great hospitality, interesting area to visit

reviews.text: The rooms are spacious, clean and simple - no phones, radio or television. There was a comfortable double bed and a single bed in each of our motel rooms, as well as a refrigerator. The outlets are few, but convenient - it might be helpful to bring an extension cord. Since it is a hunting lodge, there are some available in the main building (the lodge) with 5 single beds - just let the owners know the number of beds you need. Water pressure is good. There is no coffee in the rooms, but coffee is available in the lodge’s dining hall early in the morning. The room rates are very reasonable.
reviews.title: We would definitely come back for a return visit.

reviews.text: The lodge has a large recreation room with a pool table, reading area, pop machine and a bar (BYOB - no alcohol is sold or served at the lodge). Wireless internet is available in the main building as well (we did not try it). And on two occasions we saw mule deer very close to the lodge.
reviews.title: Highly Recommended!

reviews.text: The Tulelake area has an interesting history - both recent as well as very long term. The lodge is situated on the slope of the Gillem Bluff, a geologic fault line that was created 1.9 million years ago, and it overlooks expansive crop fields in the Tulelake Irrigation District.
reviews.title: Nice Place in the Middle of Nowhere

reviews.text: You can learn more about the volcanic build-up of the area at the nearby Lava Beds National Monument. And the Tulelake museum, near the town’s fairgrounds, does a nice job of presenting information about the local cultural/agricultural history, from the pre-historic Modoc Indian period that ended with the 1872-73 Modoc Indian War, through the settlement by pioneers and the WWII internment camp, to the problems and protest that ensued in 2001 when water to the district’s farms was shut off in the middle of the growing season.
reviews.title: Great experience!!!
Great lodging for Lava beds NM
reviews.text: Very nice lodge owners. The motel rooms were basic, but clean and comfy. The main lodge is great for sitting and chatting with others, Lava Beds National Monument was an close easy drive.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This place definitely has a hunting lodge feel to it, so if you are scared of/angered by dead animals all over walls, I wouldn't stay here. Personally, I thought it was interesting, and the service is SO friendly! The couple that runs the lodge are great, and the breakfast is delicious! The jam is amazing - you HAVE to eat some! My only complaint is that there were several mosquitos in the room, and I got bit a bunch of times, but overall we had a very positive experience, and I understand that bugs are extremely prominent since they are right on the lake.
reviews.title: Friendly staff, great breakfast, close to Lava Beds!

reviews.text: Also, keep your eye out for deer on the side of the road at night! They are everywhere!!!
reviews.title: Great Stay

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Great view of valley, accomodations are perfect for short stay. Five of us stayed in one of the Lodge Rooms and found them to be adequate size. No A/C except for the Lodge Rec Room. Great breakfast in the morning if you request it ahead of time. Very little available in town, small market and 2 places to eat. Mike and Wandas in Tulelake had good meals but they close early. Room and hearty breakfast was only $25 per person for 1 night.
reviews.title: Its kind of like staying at your own little place,

reviews.text: We planned to camp at Lava Beds National Monumnet, but an Alaskan front came in, temps 30 to 37 day time, hail storms off an on, wind chill etc. We are lava tube cavers. We stayed 3 nites at this place, and miss being there as we are now back home. Very short drive 20min to Park visitor ctr. After long days of caving the queen bed in the small motel part of the lodge was perfect, No TV was great as we could do research reading in the evenings. The host was very kind and great conversation at 7am coffee and continental breakfast in the main lodge. Price was great too. We were able to hike, crawl and squeeze long hours in the park and then have nice hot shower and comfy warm bed at night. The park was great and was like the tubes on Big but more concentrated in one spot. Recomend the park and this hunting lodge to anyone with a love of nature and people. Very clean place. Capt. Jacks Restruaunt just south of Tulelake was great food and good priced. Will go back as more caves to explore.
reviews.title: Not fancy but a great place to stay in a remote location.
